description: From Anglo-Norman remunter, Middle French remonter, later also reinforced by re- +‎ mount.

entries.meaning: The opportunity of, or things necessary for, remounting; specifically, a fresh horse, with its equipment.
(computing) The process of mounting a drive or volume again.
The restaging of a play or film.
examples: Sometimes I tell people she is auditioning for a remount of the musical “Hair”.

verbs.description: remount (third-person singular simple present remounts, present participle remounting, simple past and past participle remounted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To go up again; to rise another time. [from 15th c.]
examples: They remounted together to their sitting-room while Sir Claude, who said he would join them later, remained below to smoke and to converse with the old acquaintances that he met wherever he turned.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To help (someone) back on a horse. [from 15th c.]
(intransitive) To get back on a horse, bicycle etc. [from 15th c.]
examples: We remounted and took up the same hard tempo.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To get back on (an animal, vehicle) again. [from 16th c.]
examples: Still agitated, she watched resentfully as two traffic policemen remounted their motorcycles.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fix (something) back into position. [from 17th c.]
(transitive, computing) To mount (a drive or volume) again.
